content: The federal K-12 education legislation, starting with the Improving America's Schools Act in 1994, has focused on granting flexibility to grantees. The No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 extended and introduced new flexibility authorities. This report outlines the authorizations for state and local flexibility in administering federal K-12 education programs, with updates on major developments and impacts. The report discusses flexibility authorities in federal K-12 education programs, allowing waivers for program requirements and fund transfers among programs to broaden the use of federal aid. These authorities apply to programs authorized by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA). The report focuses on flexibility authorities in federal K-12 education programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), allowing waivers for program requirements and fund transfers. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is not included in these authorities. The report will be updated to reflect legislative developments regarding the ESEA. The report discusses flexibility authorities in federal K-12 education programs under the ESEA, excluding the IDEA. It covers program requirements, waivers, fund transfers, and legislative developments. The report will be regularly updated to reflect major changes. The report analyzes issues specific to individual authorities under the ESEA, focusing on flexibility in program requirements. These requirements can be waived for states and LEAs to ensure accountability in the use of federal funds for K-12 education programs. Federal K-12 education programs aim to ensure federal funds are used in line with program purposes, with specific requirements for pupil eligibility and fund allocation. These programs focus on student populations with special needs, specific instructional services, and innovative approaches like charter schools. Federal K-12 education programs, categorized into specific areas like instructional services and innovative approaches, are often referred to as "categorical" programs. However, the Innovative Programs authority of ESEA Title V-A is considered a "block grant" due to its support for a broad range of activities. The ESEA Title V-A Innovative Programs authority is considered a "block grant" due to its broad support for various activities. Federal requirements and guidance are provided to state and local recipients of federal aid, with a distinction between "requirements" that must be met by grantees as a matter of law. Program regulations, published in the Federal Register and integrated into the Code of Federal Regulations, supplement statutory language on complex issues prioritized by the U.S. Department of Education. Non-regulatory policy guidance is also provided by ED for many aid programs. The U.S. Department of Education publishes regulations and non-regulatory policy guidance for aid programs. Non-regulatory guidance, such as "Dear Colleague" letters, provides specific answers to program-related questions, but grantees are not legally required to follow it. The "non-regulatory" guidance provided by the U.S. Department of Education for aid programs may lead grantees to believe they will face fewer challenges if they follow it. This guidance is often treated as equivalent to regulations, even when not explicitly required. Additionally, competitive priorities set by ED for grant programs establish preferences for certain applications, such as those providing services in schools. The U.S. Department of Education sets priorities for grant programs, giving preferential consideration to applicants who meet them. These priorities are not regulations but are published in the Federal Register. There has been a trend towards less voluminous regulations for federal education programs in recent years. Since the adoption of the IASA in 1994, there has been a trend towards less voluminous regulations for federal education programs. Some programs have no regulations published, relying on statutory guidance. For programs like ESEA Title I-A, regulations are briefer and address fewer issues than before the early 1990s. The proposed program regulations for ESEA Title I-A after the IASA in 1994 took a minimalist approach, focusing on standards, assessments, accountability, schoolwide programs, private school participation, and fund allocation. The Department of Education has followed a similar strategy post-NCLB of 2001, regulating only when necessary for clarity or flexibility, with a preference for issuing nonregulatory guidance on legal and policy issues under Title I programs. The Secretary plans to issue nonregulatory guidance on legal and policy issues under Title I programs to inform schools and other parties about flexibility in meeting program requirements for federal K-12 education assistance. This guidance aims to establish accountability for the appropriate use of federal aid funds. Federal elementary and secondary education programs require accountability for the appropriate use of federal aid funds. This includes target accountability, outcome accountability, and fiscal accountability to ensure funds are focused on eligible areas, improve student achievement, and maintain financial integrity. Federal elementary and secondary education programs focus on improving student achievement and enhancing K-12 instruction. Fiscal accountability ensures that federal aid funds are used to supplement, not replace, state or local funds. Specific requirements include targeting resources to high-need pupil groups, limiting fund uses to high-priority services, and implementing minimum qualifications for schools. Federal elementary and secondary education programs have specific requirements to ensure fiscal accountability, such as targeting resources to high-need pupil groups, limiting fund uses to high-priority services, implementing minimum qualifications for school staff, and reporting program activities to parents and the public.
